insights.summary: The NeuroReach VR system offers a novel approach to stroke rehabilitation through engaging mixed-reality tasks with adaptive feedback.
insights.text: The NeuroReach VR system is designed to train stroke patients in essential reach and grasp movements using immersive mixed-reality tasks like pouring and tracing (c0001). These tasks are enhanced by multimodal feedback (visual, auditory, haptic) and a projected dashboard displaying real-time performance metrics (c0002). The system's adaptive controller dynamically adjusts difficulty and feedback based on user progress, transitioning from performance to results-based feedback as rehabilitation advances (c0002). This innovative approach aims to improve patient engagement and clinical outcomes in stroke recovery.

NeuroReach VR
Mixed Reality Project Proposal
Supervised by: Marwen Mokni, Christoph Bauer, Petar Lukovic
October 6, 2025
GROUP MEMBERS
Partha Sarathi
Purkayastha
Alexandre Elsig Raphael Fl¨uckiger Rakhmatillokhon
Khoshimov
I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

Goal: EMG biofeedback for wrist extension to complement pouring and tracing [4]. Idea: Stream Myo sEMG into

engagement and selective activation. Outcome: Quick add-on with extra KPIs (time-in-target, ratio, co-contraction)
and demo toggle mode.

Work Package 3 : Adaptive controller & logging (Weeks 6–8)
Members Responsible: A. Elsig, R. Fl¨uckiger
Description: Rule based adaptation of corridor, tilt window and tracing tunnel; feedback fading from knowledge of
performance to knowledge of results; Outcomes: Adaptive controller with hysteresis; 50 to 90 Hz logging with rolling
summaries. Challenges: Overreactive difficulty oscillation; metric drift across sessions. Solutions: Moving average
with gates and floors; buffered asynchronous writes and per trial files. Alternatives: Manual override switches;
lightweight local database if CSV grows; fixed difficulty presets.
Work Package 4 : Pilot study and analysis (Weeks 9–12)
Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Khoshimov
Description: Evaluate the system with a 5-10 participant pilot study; Test usability and performance using a baseline,
training, retention protocol to inform final refinements. Outcomes: A polished system with documentation; A formal
study protocol with a performance dataset; A completed usability and analysis report. Challenges: Participant
recruitment delays; Technical instability. Solutions: Recruit early; Conduct internal dry runs to fix bugs. Alternatives:
Use a smaller cohort; Simplify the protocol if technical issues arise.
III. OUTCOMES AND DEMONSTRATION
Expected outcomes: (i) A working proof-of-concept prototype that turns kinematics into adaptive multimodal
feedback during pouring and tracing (ii) A logging and analytics tool that summarizes on path, tilt window, spills
proxy and SPARC smoothness (iii) A small pilot indicating increased time in tilt window and reduced RMS path
error with improved SPARC, consistent with drinking task kinematics and smoothness literature [5].
Evaluation plans: (i) A preliminary usability study with physiotherapists, collecting qualitative feedback through a
think-aloud protocol and post-session questionnaires. (ii) Assess the system’s perceived effectiveness, ease of use,
and fit to ARAT aligned tasks, with specific focus on clarity of halos, ticks and result cards (iii) Focus on the
intuitiveness of the feedback mechanisms and the motivational aspect of the gamified environment, with potential
for clinical application.
Demonstration plan: (i) Live on-headset demo with quick anchor calibration, where user performs two one minute
pouring blocks and two tracing blocks with real time halos, ticks and error bars (ii) Projected dashboard shows
on path, tilt window, spills proxy, RMS error

insights.summary: Technical challenges in mixed-reality implementation are being addressed with specific solutions to ensure system stability and functionality.
insights.text: The development of the NeuroReach VR system faces technical hurdles such as anchor drift and noisy tilt estimation, for which solutions are being implemented (c0003). These include relocalizing anchors and employing filtering techniques for tilt estimation. The project also aims to deliver a functional Unity project with specific features, though the extent of these deliverables is not fully confirmed by the evidence (c0003). Overcoming these challenges is crucial for the reliable operation of the mixed-reality environment and its rehabilitation tasks.

Members Responsible: P. S. Purkayastha, R. Fl¨uckiger

insights.summary: The project's adaptive controller and logging system are designed to provide sophisticated, data-driven rehabilitation adjustments.
insights.text: Work Package 3 focuses on creating an adaptive controller and logging system to manage task parameters and feedback fading (c0004). This system is intended to achieve high logging rates and provide rolling summaries of performance metrics, while actively mitigating issues like overreactive difficulty oscillations and metric drift (c0004). Although the evidence touches upon feedback mechanisms and adaptive adjustments, it does not fully elaborate on the specifics of how these adaptive features are implemented or validated (c0002). The goal is to create a responsive system that precisely tailors the rehabilitation experience to each patient's needs.

actions.title: Deep Dive into Adaptive Controller Logic and Feedback Fading
actions.detail: The current claims mention an adaptive controller and feedback fading (c0002, c0004), but lack specific details on the algorithms, rules, and thresholds governing these adaptive adjustments. To fully understand the system's sophistication and potential clinical impact, a deeper exploration of the adaptive controller's logic and the precise mechanisms of feedback fading is required.

actions.title: Quantify the Impact of Specific Technical Solutions on System Stability
actions.detail: While claim c0003 identifies solutions for anchor drift and noisy tilt estimation, the evidence does not quantify the effectiveness of these solutions. A hypothesis is that these solutions significantly improve system stability and reduce the impact of these challenges. Further investigation is needed to measure the reduction in anchor drift and improvement in tilt estimation accuracy post-implementation.

actions.title: Validate Real-time Dashboard Metrics and Trial-by-Trial Updates
actions.detail: Claim c0002 states that a projected dashboard will display specific metrics updated per trial. However, the evidence only partially lists these metrics and does not confirm their real-time update frequency or accuracy. A next step is to verify the complete list of dashboard metrics and confirm that they are indeed updated in real-time for each trial, providing immediate feedback to clinicians and patients.

actions.title: Elaborate on the Clinical Application and User Experience of Adaptive Feedback
actions.detail: Claim c0001 suggests potential clinical application, and c0002 mentions adaptive difficulty adjustments and fading feedback. However, the specific ways in which these adaptive features will be tailored to different stroke patient profiles and how they contribute to a motivating and effective user experience are not fully detailed. Further clarification is needed on how the adaptive controller's output translates into tangible benefits for stroke rehabilitation and patient engagement.

actions.title: Confirm Scope and Completion of Unity Project Deliverables
actions.detail: Claim c0003 outlines specific deliverables for the Unity project, including a functional MX Ink tracing sample with haptic ticks and a one-tap calibration UI. The evidence does not confirm the completion or the exact scope of these deliverables. A crucial next step is to obtain confirmation and potentially demonstrations of these specific Unity project components to validate the project's progress and readiness.

challenges.claim_text: Challenges include anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support, which are being addressed through specific solutions. Solutions for anchor drift involve relocalizing anchors at the session start, and low-pass filtering and debouncing events are used for tilt estimation. The project aims to deliver a Unity project with anchors and passthrough, a functional MX Ink tracing sample with haptic ticks, and a one-tap calibration UI. Alternative approaches considered include using fiducials instead of anchors and running tracing tasks without haptics if support is inconsistent.
challenges.summary: The claim mentions specific solutions for anchor drift and tilt estimation, but the evidence does not detail these solutions.
challenges.detail: The claim states that anchor drift is addressed by relocalizing anchors at session start, and tilt estimation uses low-pass filtering and debouncing. However, the provided evidence snippets do not offer any information about these specific methods. Evidence E1 discusses 'metric drift across sessions' and solutions like 'moving average with gates and floors,' which are related but not identical to the claim's description of anchor drift solutions. Similarly, while E1 mentions 'tilt window,' it doesn't elaborate on how tilt estimation challenges are overcome.

I. DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT
Goal: To build NeuroReach VR – a proof-of-concept mixed-reality system that trains stroke reach and grasp using
an ARAT-aligned pouring task [1] and an MX Ink tracing task with visual, auditory and haptic feedback [6], to
improve selective muscle activation in the arms for stroke rehabilitation. [2].
Idea: Quest 3S with Shared Spatial Anchors pins virtual halos to a real cup and jug while MX Ink provides stylus
pose and pressure for tracing with haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse. We compute on path, time in tilt
window, spill proxy and smoothness with SPARC, and adapt difficulty to keep the user in a target corridor.
Rationale: The design draws on motor learning and control theory, emphasizing that stroke recovery combines
adaptation and skill learning to achieve specific task goals [5]. Guided by optimal feedback control, path corri-
dors, goal halos, and error-contingent cues support goal-directed corrections. Task-specific ADL movements with
validated kinematic metrics use SPARC for smoothness, while conservative auditory pacing maintains performance
consistency [3].
II. WORK PACKAGES AND TIMELINE
Hardware & Software: The system runs on Meta Quest 3S using Logitech MX Ink for precision input and haptic
feedback, with an optional Myo armband for EMG biofeedback. It is developed in Unity (C#) for Android, logs
data in CSV and JSON formats, and uses Python notebooks for quick analysis and visualization.
Work Package 1 : Data Anchors, Integration and Calibration (Weeks 1–2)
Members Responsible: R. Khoshimov, A. Elsig
Description: Set up Quest 3 passthrough and Spatial Anchors; integrate MX Ink input and haptics; implement
CSV logger. Outcomes: Unity project with anchors and passthrough; MX Ink tracing sample running with haptic
ticks; one tap calibration UI. Challenges: Anchor drift; noisy tilt estimation; inconsistent haptic support. Solutions:
Relocalize anchors at session start; low pass tilt and debounce events;. Alternatives: Use fiducials instead of anchors;
run tracing without haptics.

challenges.claim_text: Challenges include anchor drift, noisy tilt estimation, and inconsistent haptic support, which are being addressed through specific solutions. Solutions for anchor drift involve relocalizing anchors at the session start, and low-pass filtering and debouncing events are used for tilt estimation. The project aims to deliver a Unity project with anchors and passthrough, a functional MX Ink tracing sample with haptic ticks, and a one-tap calibration UI. Alternative approaches considered include using fiducials instead of anchors and running tracing tasks without haptics if support is inconsistent.
challenges.summary: The claim outlines a Unity project with specific deliverables, but the evidence does not confirm the completion or scope of these deliverables.
challenges.detail: The claim asserts that the project aims to deliver a Unity project with anchors and passthrough, a functional MX Ink tracing sample with haptic ticks, and a one-tap calibration UI. While E2 mentions the goal of building a 'proof-of-concept mixed-reality system' using Quest 3S with 'Shared Spatial Anchors' and 'MX Ink' providing stylus pose and pressure for tracing with 'haptic ticks via Unity SendHapticImpulse,' it does not confirm the delivery of a complete Unity project with passthrough or a one-tap calibration UI. E3 mentions a 'quick anchor calibration' in the demonstration plan, but not a 'one-tap calibration UI' as a deliverable.
